channel.title: Comments for page "Securing ZeroMQ: Soul of a New Certificate"

item.title: Re: Proposal
item.content:encoded: 4716 would appear to be the way forward although I couldn't see an RFC for private key format either.

item.title: Re: Proposal
item.content:encoded:
Just read http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4716.txt and it's very close to what I was designing, which was an HTTP-style header + content section wrapped in begin/end lines and limited to 72 columns.

Is there an RFC for the SSH private key format? I couldn't find it.

What I'll propose later (today) will be similar to the RFC 4716 format but with some modifications. However it's a great start, thanks for this suggestion.

item.title: Re: Proposal
item.content:encoded: And as I said above, very common and widely accepted. +1 for OpenSSH key format for just this reason.

item.title: Proposal
item.content:encoded:
Hmm, what about using OpenSSH´s public key certificate storage format, or something very similar?
Having just one line that can be copy&pasted easily seems to be a quite successful format to me, especially if you don´t need any hierarchy or web-of-trust.

item.title: Re: character encoding
item.content:encoded:
I've never been a huge fan of most cert formats at all. When I saw yours I thought "ah, something sensible".

But unfortunately that just leads on to "oh not yet another format". Basically, there already exists lots of software for creating keys that people have and use and they all output into a "commonly used format". Many of these people would be scratching their heads wondering why this new client doesn't accept any of the keys I already have *at least without a converter).

Never liked x509 but unfortunately it's out there and common :(

item.title: character encoding
item.content:encoded:
Note that this will also be used worldwide, so character encoding might be an important detail. I don't have any expertise here so I don't know what the simplest encoding would be that would support all/most languages.

Maybe it's best to just force everyone to ascii.
